DataElement.preferredName: Past Integer::4 Week Adult Malignant Neoplasm Therapy Unattractive Emotion Psychometrics Assessment Score
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric score to represent the response to a QLAC question posed to an adult about feeling unattractive over the past four weeks because of cancer or its treatment. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Past Integer::4 Week Adult Malignant Neoplasm Therapy Unattractive Emotion
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Past; before the present time._A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.::4_Any period of seven consecutive days._A human who has reached reproductive age._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process._That aspect of consciousness devoted to affect or feeling; a strong feeling, aroused mental state, or intense state of drive or unrest directed toward a definite object, with physiological, somatic, and behavioral components.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Past; before the present time.:A number with no fractional part.::4:Any period of seven consecutive days.:A human who has reached reproductive age.

Concepts.definition: A number with no fractional part, including the negative and positive numbers as well as zero.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An age group comprised of humans who have reached reproductive age.

Property.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.:That aspect of consciousness devoted to affect or feeling; a strong feeling, aroused mental state, or intense state of drive or unrest directed toward a definite object, with physiological, somatic, and behavioral components.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

That aspect of consciousness devoted to affect or feeling; a strong feeling, aroused mental state, or intense state of drive or unrest directed toward a definite object, with physiological, somatic, and behavioral components.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Process and results associated with self-reported measures and instruments, surveys, other tools

DataElementConcept.origin: QLAC:Quality of Life in Adult Cancer Survivors Scale
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated to support the Quality of Life in Adult Cancer Survivors Scale (QLAC), a validated psychometric measure developed by Dr. Nancy E. Avis

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The science of measuring "psychological" aspects of a person such as knowledge, skills, abilities, or personality. Measurement of these unobservable phenomena is difficult and much of the research and accumulated art of this discipline is designed to reliably define and then quantify._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability._A number or range of numeric values measuring performance, function, quality, or ability.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: At all times; on every occasion.

Concepts.definition: At all times; on every occasion.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not ever; at no time in the past (or future).

Measurement of these unobservable phenomena is difficult and much of the research and accumulated art of this discipline is designed to reliably define and then quantify.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Curated to support creation of CCR PI questions about CTCL of the skin; to be combined with Skindex measure.

ReferenceDocuments.name: You felt unattractive because
ReferenceDocuments.description: You felt unattractive because of your cancer or its treatment.
